case_name: Satrughan v. Subujpari and Sujan Devi

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 939 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 939 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 28, 1958 of Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 458 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 28, 1958 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 458 of 1951.

facts.text: Musamat Chando Kuer instituted suit on April 23, 1949 in Court of Subordinate Judge, Darbhanga.

anchor.surface_text: Musamat Chando Kuer, widow of Babuji, instituted a suit on April 23, 1949 in the Court of the Sabordinate Judge, Darbhanga,

facts.text: Suit against collaterals of her husband Babuji for partition and separate possession of half share in Schedules A to E and fourth share in Sch. F.

anchor.surface_text: against the companylaterals of her husband for a decree for partition and separate possession of a half share in the properties described in Schedules A to E and a fourth share in Sch. F

facts.text: Chando Kuer claimed Babuji separated in 1934 from coparcenary.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of Chando Kuer that her husband Babuji separated in 1934 from the companyarcenary of which he was a member,

facts.text: Babuji died on October 28, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: and on his death on October 28, 1937 his share in the family property devolved upon her,

facts.text: Defendants failed to divide estate and deliver share to Chando Kuer.

anchor.surface_text: but the defendants failed and neglected to divide the estate and deliver to her the share inherited by her.

facts.text: Suit resisted by collaterals of Babuji.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the companylaterals of Babuji.

facts.text: Chando Kuer died on March 9, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Chando Kuer died on March 9, 1951,

facts.text: Daughters Subujpari and Sujan Devi brought on record as heirs and legal representatives of Chando Kuer.

anchor.surface_text: and her daughters Subujpari and Sujan Devi  hereinafter companylectively called the appellants  were brought on the record of the suit as her heirs and legal representatives.

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed suit, holding no separation of Babuji in 1934 and interest devolved by survivorship.

anchor.surface_text: Being of the opinion that the plea of separation of Babuji from the companyarcenary in 1934 was number established, and that the interest of Babuji in the companyercenary property devolved upon the surviving companyarceners, the Trial Court dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Patna High Court in appeal granted decree for possession of share as at date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the High Court of Judicature at Patna, granted a decree for possession of a share in the property as at the date of the suit.

facts.text: High Court held Chando Kuer acquired interest under Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act, 1937 on Babuji's death.

anchor.surface_text: The held that on the death of Babuji on October 28, 1937, Chando Kuer by virtue of the Hindu Womens Rights to Property Act, IS of 1937, acquired in the property of the companyarcenary the same interest which Babuji had,

facts.text: High Court held interest defined by institution of suit and devolved to appellants on Chando Kuer's death.

anchor.surface_text: and by the institution of the suit for partition that interest became defined, and oil her death it devolved upon the appellants as heirs to the estate of Babuji.

facts.text: Satrughan, son of Ghiran, appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, Satrughan the son of Ghiran has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Trial Court finding that Babuji did not separate in 1934 not challenged in High Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On the finding recorded by the Trial Court which was number challenged in appeal before the High Court, Babuji did number separate in 1934 from the other companyarceners.

facts.text: Babuji died in October 1937.

anchor.surface_text: But he died in October 1937

facts.text: Chando Kuer invested with husband's interest by Act 18 of 1937 as modified by Bihar Act 6 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: and by the operation of Act 18 of 1937 as modified by Bihar Act 6 of 1942 Chando Kuer was invested with her husbands interest in the companyarcenary property agricultural as well as number-agricultural.

facts.text: Chando Kuer instituted suit for partition, making interest defined.

anchor.surface_text: When she instituted a suit for partition that interest became de- fined, and vested in her free from all claims or rights of the companyarceners of her husband.

facts.text: Right of coparceners to take interest by survivorship extinguished on Chando Kuer's death after suit.

anchor.surface_text: The right of the companyarceners to take that interest by survivorship on Chando Kuers death was then extinguished.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Province of Bihar enacted Act VI of 1942 extending Act 18 of 1937 to agricultural lands retrospectively from April 14, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: but the Province of Bihar enacted Act VI of 1942 extending the operation of Act 18 of 1937 to agricultural lands in Bihar with retrospective effect from April 14, 1937.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: Sarjoo Prasad, Indu Shekhar Prasad Sinha, B. P. Singh, Anil Kumar Sablok and U. P. Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Sarjoo Prasad, Indu Shekhar Prasad Sinha, B. P. Singh. Anil Kumar Sablok and U. P. Singh, for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: B. Datar, Vineet Kumar and K. R. Chaudhury, for the respondent No. 9.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of Act 18 of 1937 as amended by Act 1 1 of 1938 insofar as it is material in this appeal  is 3.  1  When a Hindu governed by any school of Hindu law other than the Dayabhaga school or by customary law dies having at the time of his death an interest in a Hindu joint family property, his widow shall, subject to the provisions of subsection  3 , have the same interest as he himself had.

issues.text: whether the right of the coparceners to take her interest on determination of the widow's interest survives even after the interest has become definite, because of a claim for partition

anchor.surface_text: To assume as has been done in some decided cases that the right of the companyarceners to take her interest on determination of the widows interest survives even after the interest has become definite, because of a claim for partition, is to denude the right to claim partition of all reality.

issues.text: whether the expression partition in S. 3(3) means not merely severance of status, but division of interest by metes and bounds followed by assumption of exclusive possession by the widow

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that the right vested in the surviving companyarceners to take the interest vested in the widow enures so long as the widow does number, by suit or by private arrangement reduce her interest in the property of the companyarcenary to exclusive possession. He submitted that the expression partition in S. 3 3  means number merely severance of status, but division of interest by metes and bounds followed by assumption of exclusive possession by the widow.

arguments.claim: Parappagari case correctly states: if widow partitions, devolves as husband's separate property

anchor.surface_text: The following observations made by Subba Rao., J., in delivering the judgment of the Full Bench in Parappagari Parappa alias Hanumanthappa and Another- v. Parappagari Nagamma and L.R. 63 I. A. 33.  2  I.L.R. 1954 Mad. 257.

arguments.claim: Chando Kuer's suit defined interest free from coparceners' rights; survivorship extinguished on her death

anchor.surface_text: The right of the companyarceners to take that interest by survivorship on Chando Kuers death was then extinguished.

holdings.text: Babuji did not separate in 1934 from the other coparceners.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court finding not challenged in High Court appeal; accepted as fact.

holdings.text: Chando Kuer was invested with her husband's interest in the coparcenary property (agricultural as well as non-agricultural) by the operation of Act 18 of 1937 as modified by Bihar Act 6 of 1942.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of HWRTPA 1937 extended retrospectively by Bihar Act to all lands upon husband's death.

holdings.text: When Chando Kuer instituted the suit for partition, her interest became defined and vested in her free from all claims or rights of the coparceners of her husband.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Institution of suit equates to claim for partition, severing status and defining fluctuating interest per statutory right equivalent to male coparcener.

holdings.text: The right of the coparceners to take that interest by survivorship on Chando Kuer's death was then extinguished.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-partition claim, survivorship suspended right is fully extinguished; interest devolves as separate property to husband's heirs, giving reality to partition right.

holdings.text: A widow invested with her husband's interest under the Act does not become a coparcener and does not acquire rights over other coparceners' interests.

anchor.surface_text: But the widow does not on that account become a coparcener though invested with the same interest which her husband had in the property she does not acquire the right which her husband could have exercised over the interest of the other coparceners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory substitution introduces widow but preserves coparcenary structure among males; no mutual rights.

holdings.text: The right of other coparceners to take the widow's interest by survivorship remains suspended during her estate but stands extinguished if she claims partition.

anchor.surface_text: Because of statutory substitution of her interest in the coparcenary property in place of her husband, the right which the other coparceners had under the Hindu law of the Mitakshara school of taking that interest by the rule of survivorship remains suspended so long as that estate enures.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dissolution on husband's death; partition severs widow, defining and separating her share permanently.

holdings.text: If the widow claims partition and her estate terminates, her interest in coparcenary property devolves upon the heirs of her husband.

anchor.surface_text: If she dies after partition or her estate is otherwise determined, the interest in coparcenary property which has vested in her will devolve upon the heirs of her husband.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act silent on devolution post-partition; partition right as male owner means interest becomes separate, devolving per succession not survivorship.

holdings.text: Partition under Section 3(3) does not mean merely severance of status but includes it; does not require division by metes and bounds and exclusive possession.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted that the expression partition in S. 3 3  means not merely severance of status, but division of interest by metes and bounds followed by assumption of exclusive possession by the widow. There is no warrant for this submission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellant's narrow view; follows Judicial Committee in Girja Bai that partition includes adjustment of rights/severance of title via suit.

holdings.text: The widow acquires the same right to claim partition as a male owner, which defines her interest upon demand.

anchor.surface_text: The widow acquires by statute the same right to claim partition which a male owner has, and as pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Girja Bai v. Sadashiv Dhundiraj and Others In Hindu law, partition does not mean division of property into specific shares it covers both division of title and division of property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory conferment mirrors male coparcener's right; per Mitakshara commentators, includes ascertainment of shares via claim.

holdings.text: Dicta in Movva Subba Rao, Shamrao Bhagvantrao, and Bhagabai are incorrect; widow's interest post-partition does not revert to coparcenary.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inconsistent with statutory right to partition and Hindu law principles; denude partition right of reality.

holdings.text: Observations in Parappagari Parappa correctly state the law: post-partition, devolves as husband's separate property to his heirs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Aligns with purposive effect of Act and partition severance.

anchor.surface_text: but by statutory substitution Lakshmi Perumallu v. Krishnavenamma 1 . Her interest in the property is the limited interest known as a Hindu womans estate but the Act gives her the same power to claim partition as a male owner has.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted that the expression partition in S. 3 3  means not merely severance of status, but division of interest by metes and bounds followed by assumption of exclusive possession by the widow. There is no warrant for this submission.

He submitted that the expression partition in S. 3 3  means not merely severance of status, but division of interest by metes and bounds followed by assumption of exclusive possession by the widow. There is no warrant for this submission.

The widow acquires by statute the same right to claim partition which a male owner has, and as pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Girja Bai v. Sadashiv Dhundiraj and Others In Hindu law, partition does not mean division of property into specific shares it covers both division of title and division of property.
